query: I'm moving from southampton to Southampton. Will I need a new care needs assessment or can my current care package transfer?

retrieved_documents.content: I’m moving to Southampton You can view our page about moving to Southampton to get all the information you’ll need, including Council Tax and bins information. Moving into Southampton with adult social care needs If you receive support to meet your daily living needs from your current Local Authority please ensure you have spoken to a social worker in your local area about your move. Under The Care Act 2014 it is the duty of your existing Local Authority to ensure Southampton City Council is aware of your move, has a copy of your most recent assessment and that support is put in place in a timely way to ensure your needs are met from your point of arrival. If you currently self-fund your support and have not had a recent assessment from your current Local Authority but need advice on what is available in Southampton, please see our directory of services for adults or visit our page My health makes it difficult to look after myself

If you have ongoing care and support needs which are assessed as being eligible

and the Isle of Wight. Southampton is a local area within the integrated care system, this strategy refects the needs of Southampton. It also looks at where our services reach outside our local area to make sure they’re linked up. 
This new strategy sets out 5 priorities we need to focus on to promote the health and well-being

Paying For Residential Care - Factsheet

Paying for residential care - information from Southampton City Council about how you will need to contribute towards the cost of your residential care

If you decide that staying in your own home is no longer right for you then you and your care manager can talk about the kind of residential or nursing home you need. Moving into residential care is a big decision and can have major financial implications.

If you have over £23,250 in savings you will be required to pay for the full costs of your care. If you have less than this amount in savings you may be entitled to financial help if it is agreed by you and social services that this is the best kind of care for you.

If you wish to move into residential care and you have sufficient income and resources to pay for this yourself, you may arrange this independently. However, if most of your assets are tied up in your home, you may still wish to approach the council for help.

answer:
When moving to Southampton, you will need to ensure that your current Local Authority communicates with Southampton City Council about your move and provides them with your most recent care needs assessment. **Under The Care Act 2014, your current Local Authority is responsible for informing Southampton City Council of your move and ensuring that support is in place from your arrival.**

- **If you have a current care package:** Your existing Local Authority should send your most recent assessment to Southampton City Council, who will then ensure that your needs are met upon your arrival.
- **If you self-fund and have not had a recent assessment:** You should contact Southampton City Council for advice on available services. You can use their directory of services for adults or visit their page for more information.

**Practical Next Steps:**
- Speak to a social worker in your current area about your move.
- Contact Southampton City Council’s Adult Social Care Connect at 023 8083 3003 or visit [southampton.gov.uk/health-social-care](https://www.southampton.gov.uk/health-social-care) for more information or to request an assessment or review of your care and support needs.

According to the documents, if Southampton City Council does not make a decision about your care and support before your move, they must initially meet the needs identified by your first Local Authority. If they later decide differently about your eligible needs, they must explain why.
